metadata.sermon_title: The Living God More Than “Tastes Great ... Less Filling”
metadata.sermon_start_end: When I looked at the texts designated for this Sunday, I was reminded that the church is not unlike the familiar beer commercial of “tastes great ... less filling.” As you likely know, in the beer ad, each party of the beer-drinking crowd has determined a point of view [...] Imagine, Easter is a surge of the living God, every day, for this is the God who holds nothing back of God’s own self from us.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific passage. It treats Psalm 146 and Hebrews 9 as two poles of a sociological tension. It does not find what is unique to Psalm 146 that can be found nowhere else; instead, it uses the texts as illustrations for a general theory about church polarities.
quotes: I puzzled at the text, Hebrews 9... and Psalm 146 that has God in solidarity with all the social rejects
Hebrews 9 ... Psalm 146, lessons for the day
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope. Abandon the 'balancing' of two texts and dig into the specific linguistic and theological particularity of Psalm 146 alone.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of original language study or historical-critical depth. The 'exposition' is limited to a thematic summary of the verses. The original context of the post-exilic community or the specific nature of the 'princes' in the Psalm is ignored in favor of modern analogies.
quotes: The statement appeals to the ancient rituals from the book of Leviticus
The Psalm exhibits God as the one who is transforming the political economy of society.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific historical context of Israel's trust in God versus human 'princes' and use the Hebrew nuances of the text to drive the argument.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is broad and sociological. While it mentions 'banks' and 'health care,' it treats them as categories of a 'progressive' worldview rather than concrete applications for the specific congregation. It remains at the level of 'zeitgeist' analysis without becoming a personal call to the hearer.
quotes: Progressives... get our own hands involved in issues of power, money, health care, housing, prison reform
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move from describing 'progressive' and 'conservative' views to addressing the hearer's specific life and choices in the light of the text.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a thematic essay. It moves from a beer commercial to a sociological observation, then uses the Bible to support these observations. The hearer is not drawn into the text; the text is drawn into the preacher's pre-existing framework of church conflict.
quotes: On the one hand a conservative construal... On the other hand, a liberal or progressive view
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Start with the text's own movement and let the application emerge from the exposition of the words themselves.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The element of misery is present in the 'dead works' and 'hopelessness,' and redemption is linked to the 'living God.' However, it is somewhat 'soft.' The misery is framed as a sociological 'tension' rather than a fundamental state before God.
quotes: purified our consciences from dead works
if you know about deathly shadows of hopelessness in your life
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by showing how both 'conservative' and 'progressive' slogans can be 'dead works' that fail to reach the living God.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions the choice between 'powerful agents of control' and the 'living God,' but it lacks the 'seriousness of being lost.' The tone is more about 'giving up energy' than the ultimate destination of man.
quotes: if you are using your energy to become a powerful agent of control, give it up
When we live by what is possible by us, we either end in despair
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Thematize the 'lostness' of trusting in 'princes' (mortals) as a literal path to destruction, as the Psalm implies.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos' and linked to the 'Easter God.' The doctrine of grace is present, particularly in the emphasis on receiving rather than 'hustling.' However, Christ is used more as a bridge between two theological camps than the specific center of the text.
quotes: this God who came bodied in Jesus of Nazareth
the living God emerged from the power of death on Easter day
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'resolution' to a sociological problem but the specific fulfillment of the Psalm's promise.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1250 words, the sermon would take about 12-13 minutes to deliver. According to Dekker (Thesis 8), this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the sermon to at least 20 minutes by deepening the exegetical engagement with the specific text.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily because it is a thematic speech about church polarities rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. It lacks the required length for depth and relies on a sociological framework (the 'beer commercial' analogy) rather than allowing the text to dictate the structure. The exegesis is thin, and the application is general rather than concrete.
strengths: Clear attempt to address the zeitgeist of church polarization.
Strong emphasis on the 'living' nature of God as opposed to static dogmas.
Correctly identifies the need for grace over human effort ('hustling').
weaknesses: Fails the formal definition of a sermon by using two texts as mere illustrations for a pre-conceived theme.
Duration is significantly below the 20-minute threshold required for depth.
Exegesis of the original context is almost entirely absent.
The 'two ways' are presented as psychological options rather than ultimate existential possibilities.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a theological-sociological address. It lacks the specific focus on one pericope and the necessary length to provide the 'breadth' that depth requires.
